title: Kenya: Don't Be Quick to Reject Ababu Salary Proposal
text:
Kenya: Tutors Urged to Stay Away From Schools editorial 
Budalangi MP Ababu Namwamba has filed a motion in Parliament for top public officers to take a 50 per cent pay cut to contain the huge government wage bill. 
Even if MPs decline to have their salaries halved and the motion fails, it is still a valid effort by the MP. And it is likely to be defeated because MPs will predictably argue that their salaries are committed to mortgages, loans and other expenses. 
Nevertheless, MPs should not be quick to reject Ababu's proposal, and should at least debate it soberly. 
Parliament, the judiciary, some offices in the executive and the many constitutional commissions gobble up a huge chunk of salaries paid by the state. 
Any group of public servants agitating for a pay rise finds it difficult to accept the oft-used excuse that there is no money, when they know how much these top public servants earn. 
The many commissions that handle issues of citizens' rights should be merged to save money, including the Kenya National Commission on Human Rights, the Gender Commission and the Commission on the Administration of Justice. 
Others like the Transition Authority, whose usefulness has passed with the implementation of the constitution, should be dissolved. 
The public wage bill, taking up 52 per cent of all money collected by Kenya Revenue Authority, is indeed unsustainable and initiatives like voluntary early retirement for public servants should also be explored.
